document.title: Fischer Copy of 2020-2021 Physics Curriculum Map

C676151276324471AD76A935CBF59CA7.description: I CAN calculate the number of beats heard per second when two close frequencies are played.

D53FD4AF4986496BB380E5BA04647CEA.description: I CAN describe the principle of resonance and apply it to new situations.

BB5D03766D5F45A6A58483E63EA8D606.description: PI.7.7 Qualitatively describe the phenomena of both resonance frequencies and beat frequencies that arise from the interference of sound waves of slightly different frequency and define the beat frequency as the difference between the frequencies of two individual sound wave sources.

750917F4E264421E82B0EA2641094430.description: I CAN describe the interaction of two waves or pulses by applying the principle of superposition.

834A5AA408C24F89BC15C034435391C3.description: PI.7.6 Qualitatively and quantitatively apply the principle of superposition to describe the interaction of two mechanical waves or pulses.

7E2978AEDCAB47B68E04DB721F647FB4.description: I CAN predict the effects of changing either the frequency or the wavelength of a mechanical wave.

44A153ED39204E0887C3507C80010622.description: I CAN develop a mathematical model that relates the frequency and wavelength of a wave.

F67C4110E76D496B86BA6B9590A56070.description: PI.7.3 Develop graphical and mathematical representations that describe the relationship between the frequency of a mechanical wave and the wavelength of the wave and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the frequency of a mechanical wave affects the wavelength and vice versa.

2CEDD3FBA72E4BF0B7D4EAF87F12DC1A.description: I CAN differentiate between various forms of mechanical waves (transverse, longitudinal)

49732610309C4EE0919AA701F333842B.description: PI.7.1 Differentiate between transverse and longitudinal modes of oscillation for a mechanical wave traveling in one dimension.

DC8F95D4EA2E44319C39B7CB24E35134.description: I CAN apply the models of simple harmonic motion to a simple pendulum system.

95E6F9E1518F41158F8D992663B84A02.description: I CAN apply the models of simple harmonic motion to a mass-spring system.

E63204A1461B4BFEB3EBA46CF4F273B1.description: I CAN develop a mathematical model that relates the stretching of a spring to the restoring force (Hooke's Law).

AF0EF1A50E0A4792917772CE309CD397.description:
PI 6.1  Develop graphical and mathematical representations that describe the relationship between the amount of stretch of a spring and the restoring force and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the stretch or compression will affect the restoring force and vice versa, specifically for an ideal spring.		
		
PI.6.3  Develop graphical and mathematical representations which describe the relationship between the mass, elastic constant, and period of a simple horizontal mass-spring system and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the mass or elastic constant will affect the period of the system for an ideal spring.		
		
PI.6.4 Develop graphical and mathematical representations which describe the relationship between the strength of gravity, length of string, and period of a simple mass-string (i.e. pendulum) system apply the those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the length of string or strength of gravity will affect the period of the system in the limit of small amplitudes.

EDABFB412B74431C9C3669983D28D428.description: I CAN use a schematic diagram to calculate unknown values for current, voltage, and resistance in electric circuits.

79FE090899FA41B4BE2A91F52FAE16BC.description: PI 8.9  Use a description or schematic diagram of an electrical circuit to calculate unknown values of current, voltage, or resistance in various components or branches of the circuit according to Ohm’s Law, Kirchhoff’s junction rule, and Kirchhoff’s loop rule.

95044DAAB0B34C00A0B292AA3A27DC8B.description: I CAN use Ohm's Law and the Power Law to analyze parallel circuits and make predictions under laboratory conditions.

70638D6370AD428AA830FC6D5021B336.description: PI 8.6  Qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the voltage or resistance of a simple parallel (i.e. ladder) circuit affects the voltage, current, and power measurements of individual resistive devices and for the entire circuit.

7A1706C7B7A645789CA7D2E28E7DF3C5.description: I CAN use Ohm's Law and the Power Law to analyze series circuits and make predictions under laboratory conditions.

20A56C576A624512B91A45016330EF16.description: PI 8.5  Qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the voltage or resistance of a simple series (i.e. loop) circuit affects the voltage, current, and power measurements of individual resistive devices and for the entire circuit.

EE2B0BC61E1241E68ED0B0EB75098760.description: I CAN determine the electrical resistance of a circuit by calculating the slope of a voltage vs. current graph.

61E9ACF7BB1C4C42ABB2108A496A400D.description: PI.8.4  Describe the slope of the graphical representation of current vs. voltage or voltage vs. current in terms of the resistance of the device.

4816013E29FE49A8A0A5AA4BEBC6EE14.description: I CAN use graphs to express the relationship between electric current and voltage subject to Ohm's Law.

C89494026434498DBB6E05B01A337218.description: PI 8.3  Develop graphical and mathematical representations that describe the relationship between the amount of current passing through an ohmic device and the amount of voltage (i.e. EMF) applied across the device according to Ohm’s Law and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how changing the current affects the voltage and vice versa.

DDBFBBA5BCF24EFBBC93E2B96FA4C982.description: I CAN use visual and physical models to predict initial and final energy values of an isolated system.

E4404390335C407E91E26DC4F837A9A8.description: I CAN use multiple representations (visual, graphical, mathematical) to predict changes in mechanical energy of a system.

6C71E73DACC74A80856CE513686144E7.description: PI.4.6  Develop and apply pictorial, mathematical or graphical representations to qualitatively and quantitatively predict changes in the mechanical energy (e.g. translational kinetic, gravitational, or elastic potential) of a system due to changes in position or speed of objects or non-conservative interactions within the system.

5D6F069E0D7045C5817357FAE7D5294B.description: I CAN apply the principle of conservation of mechanical energy to all closed systems with no dissipative forces.

6D11B3520E774CD9896FFB7D17A00AB4.description: PI.4.5  Understand and apply the principle of conservation of energy to determine the total mechanical energy stored in a closed system and mathematically show that the total mechanical energy of the system remains constant as long as no dissipative (i.e. non-conservative) forces are present.

C6D417358619439AB9F0E2E2F75E654C.description: I CAN use the mathematical model to calculate work done on or by a system.

C2FE3CC34B744225B35F85DAC87434D3.description: PI.4.4  For a force exerted in one or two dimensions, mathematically determine the amount of work done on a system by an unbalanced force over a change in position in one dimension

ACEA701AEB144B9CAD4E119848271780.description: I CAN distinguish among the different forms of energy in practical scenarios.

91FC1CFB45DC4126B576AF196273093F.description: PI.4.2  Identify the forms of energy present in a scenario and recognize that the potential energy associated with a system of objects and is not stored in the object itself.

3787A010071A4434A4C14746583D56AD.description: I CAN calculate the elastic potential energy of a system using a mathematical model.

52CADC3C682C4FBE89A787ED35BCBC51.description: I CAN calculate the gravitational potential energy of a system using a mathematical model.

A57E144114484D2784E30B30827B170F.description: I CAN calculate the translational kinetic energy of a system using the mathematical model.

CD9CA2A67A8F460FA4B81D09CCA010F2.description: PI 4.1  Evaluate the translational kinetic, gravitational potential, and elastic potential energies in simple situations using the mathematical definitions of these quantities and mathematically relate the initial and final values of the translational kinetic, gravitational potential, and elastic potential energies in the absence of a net external force.

FFFC5FA1E49A4A60AAB85B4E99BEB281.description: I CAN show an inverse relationship between mass and change in velocity for collisions.

10398DEF438B4428A10376D4DAC7CF39.description: I CAN use Newton's Third Law of motion to predict the outcome of a collision.

814ED34352B24325A986AD661179B726.description: I CAN demonstrate conservation of linear momentum for collisions.

DA09D2A05A7649F58EDA80312031BEB8.description: PI.5.3  Demonstrate that when two objects interact through a collision or separation that both the force experienced by each object and change in linear momentum of each object are equal and opposite, and as the mass of an object increases, the change in velocity of that object decreases.

6ED185A010AA49BDB753134F0A0BA4D5.description: I CAN predict the change in linear momentum of an object from the average force exerted on the object and time interval during which the force is exerted.

30404E141DDF4552A13D4F929FDA9DAC.description: PI.5.2  Operationally define “impulse” as the area under a force vs. change in clock reading (time) curve and be able to determine the change in linear momentum of a system acted on by an external force. Predict the change in linear momentum of an object from the average force exerted on the object and time interval during which the force is exerted.

44C2D63531444FA78685342B5BE76628.description: I CAN calculate the linear momentum of a single object.

0D0E6E429B8749BAA2289D13A19B5860.description:
"PI 5.1  For an object moving at constant rate, define linear momentum as the product of an object’s mass and its velocity and be able to quantitatively determine the linear momentum of a single object.
"

22957D7EE18544A6A0A0759420DBCEBB.description: I CAN make predictions about situations by analyzing Newton's Third Law diagrams.

D60251DB0785472D8B2B4DAF99E38BFA.description: PI 3.4  Understand Newton’s third law of motion and describe the interaction of two objects using Newton’s third law and the representation of action-reaction pairs of forces.

0EDAAAD0CE9E4D4AA5372D28A13CA1B9.description: I CAN construct a force diagram showing multiple objects to show force pairs under Newton's Third Law.

086A8C3E5EB5406C82F2E8555AF52348.description: I CAN analyze free body diagrams to determine information about an object's state of motion.

291713FB822848219BB813B038981930.description: I CAN construct free body diagrams for objects not in equilibrium

4D09F2CCF36949A8A2A4E799D6BAA0B2.description: I CAN construct free body diagrams for objects in static equilibrium.

7E65C86F43414D7896CD63FC4BB2688C.description: PI 3.3  Construct force diagrams using appropriately labeled vectors with magnitude, direction, and units to qualitatively and quantitatively analyze a scenario and make claims (i.e. develop arguments, justify assertions) about forces exerted on an object by other objects for different types of forces or components of forces.

C1F37A1502D3493985D0140640595924.description: I CAN cite evidence to show how a net external force changes the motion of an object.

1C682DC21F7845928FF40347751EA9A1.description: I CAN  experimentally discover the relationships among total force, mass, and acceleration.

FD129E5E39234C13ACC7EF414EE4A047.description: I CAN develop graphs which correctly relate inertial mass, applied forces, and acceleration.

1367AE7B72134F4CB57595E5C96027DE.description: PI 3.2  Develop graphical and mathematical representations that describe the relationship among the inertial mass of an object, the total force applied, and the acceleration of an object in one dimension where one or more forces is applied to the object and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe how a net external force changes the motion of an object.

70AD641690424ACD8875DD7FDDCB95E0.description: I CAN interpret the motion of an object with no net external force (Newton's first law).

AAFEBEF574EC42FF80C144319E634A9F.description: PI 3.1  Understand Newton’s first law of motion and describe the motion of an object in the absence of a net external force according to Newton’s first law.

A21771516B63495E99CD9003682F4BC5.description: I CAN calculate position and velocity of an object in free fall using equations.

B194C1C7153F48B0B27B4067CF4DC6C9.description: I CAN describe the motion of an object in free fall by interpreting graphs.

42F3DF714133489CAE5B022F86C0E59C.description: PI.2.5  Qualitatively and quantitatively apply the models of constant velocity and constant acceleration to determine the position or velocity of an object moving in free fall near the surface of the Earth.

6376F6D5F6E144309C7E4D2D27EBAA4F.description: I CAN interpret velocity vs. time graphs to describe the motion of an object

F7703EFEEC8B4BED80DEFB895D5CF690.description: PI.2.2  Describe the slope of the graphical representation of velocity vs. clock reading (time) in terms of the acceleration of the object.

468043D956514474B7C5DC87746D8F4C.description: I CAN interpret a motion map to describe the motion of an object.

56ECD10E1BB74B5B96AC78037D4F861D.description: I CAN use a mathematical  model (equation) to calculate information about position, velocity, and time of an object.

1278997F22D44341B655969FC30E878B.description: I CAN develop a motion map which relates the velocity and acceleration of an object to time.

8C52C54F718B430C8C114304B3C99E36.description: I CAN develop a mathematical model which relates velocity and acceleration of an object to time.

B335D9CA679F41DEBE226DEC224AB89A.description: I CAN develop a graph which relates velocity  of an object to time.

E19DB04E8E0D48D697A9549EEA79A9BB.description: PI 2.1  Develop graphical, mathematical, and pictorial representations (e.g. a motion map) that describe the relationship between the clock reading (time) and velocity of an object moving at a uniformly changing rate and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe the motion of an object.

FB2F07657D4B40B19BDA0E98371A56A9.description: I CAN use the operational definitions to differentiate between these vocabulary terms

B299DF54825C475EAB346FF4D132978B.description: I CAN define operationally the terms distance, displacement, speed, velocity, average speed, and average velocity.

8BB26070C9DB467EB53C79371C3A0B67.description: PI.1.4 Describe the differences between the terms “distance,” “displacement,” “speed,” “velocity,” “average speed,” and “average velocity” and be able to calculate any of those values given an object moving at a single constant velocity or with different constant velocities over a given time interval.

7B27B4006CED4BE0B1F89E8FB7935246.description: I CAN interpret position vs. time graphs to describe the motion of an object

8D84F32E05AC40FF96612C4BDE244C0E.description: PI.1.2 Describe the slope of the graphical representation of position vs. clock reading (time) in terms of the velocity of the object.

086A370F09054B24BADDFFCF7DC7E4A1.description: I CAN use a mathematical  model (equation) to calculate information about position and time of an object.

968B2821B3F649C69F2103FE11C35874.description: I CAN develop a mathematical model which relates position of an object to time.

B6C84E94F54F4EA1A8F6E850A108F886.description: I CAN develop a graph which relates position of an object to time.

7BCE73A5D63C431AAF97FAC11BA2815B.description: I CAN develop a motion map which relates the position of an object to time.

F20A8EC620D64DCEA27F07A0F39BF6DA.description: I CAN interpret a motion map to describe the motion of an object.

420C0AE324F44138B27DB6BFEDE96B8B.description: PI.1.1 Develop graphical, mathematical, and pictorial representations (e.g. a motion map) that describe the relationship between the clock reading (time) and position of an object moving at a uniform rate and apply those representations to qualitatively and quantitatively describe the motion of an object.

E6B18E17BF644F009D91A802D04DFAA8.description: Constructing explanations (for science) and designing solutions (for engineering)

D465216896EC408E96EA2836AB5860A4.description: Developing and using models and tools

18C618B276E34C62A914E5DEE4F81E8C.description: Posing questions (for science) and defining problems (for engineering)
